entry.et: Middle English appel, from Old English æppel; akin to Old High German apful apple, Old Irish ubull, Old Church Slavic ablŭko

def.dt: :the fleshy usually rounded red, yellow, or green edible pome fruit of a usually cultivated tree (genus Malus) of the rose family
:a fruit (as a star apple) or other vegetative growth (as an oak apple) suggestive of an apple
:one that is highly cherished his daughter is the apple of his eye
:a thick brown spread made by cooking apples with sugar and spices usually in cider
:having cheeks the color of red apples apple–cheeked youngsters
:a dipteran fly (Rhagoletis pomonella) whose larva burrows in and feeds especially on apples
:of, relating to, or characterized by traditionally American values (as honesty or simplicity) is the epitome of apple–pie wholesomeness

entry.et: from the traditional practice of schoolchildren bringing a shiny apple as a gift to their teacher

def.dt: :a disease of apple trees caused by a fungus (Venturia inaequalis) producing dark blotches or lesions on the leaves, fruit, and sometimes the young twigs
town SE California N of San Bernardino pop 54,239
:the projection in the front of the neck formed by the largest cartilage of the larynx
